So many expressions have taken place between Johnston, me, and Cleasby, that I really cannot recollect; our business was altogether - Johnston has said,"I don't want this person to know this - and the other to know that;" he employed me and Cleasby to sell his goods in different parts of the town for cash, as there were so many bills coming due; and he took care never to have any body present but us.

COURT. Q. Did you ever know him deliver goods to Cleasby, to bring him the money for them? A. I have known him deliver him goods to sell where he could, for cash or bills; he has sold to different people at Shadwell, and I have seen them divide the profits - I know the goods in question were at Read's, the cloth-worker, in Dudley-court, Silver-street; Cleasby told me they were pawned there - I never knew him employed as a porter; if he was going to the west-end of the town he has brought a cloth for Johnston, and I have done so for him; these letters are addressed to me - Cleasby got orders for goods, and sometimes Johnston let him have them on sale or return - he used to deal with me in the same way; I have seen them divide the profits.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Where did they divide the profits? A. At the Bird Cage, Wood-street; I had a good opinion of Cleasby.

Q. If he has said you made a dupe of him, should he be believed? A. Certainly not; if he said so it is a deliberate falsehood - I always acted honestly to him and the prosecutor; I know Johnston so well, he is capable of any thing.
MR. WILKINSON. Johnston has not paid me the bill, but he has given me security for it.
The following are the letters which were read.
September 18, 1831.

MR. SYKES, - Now pray do your best to-morrow; I am sure you would if you knew how much depends on it - if we can but retrieve the mischief Cleasby has done this time, another chance of living will be left - return as soon as you can, for I am all anxiety; see that Cleasby is provided with the amount of the cut he bought yesterday, as also the black so long standing; you know it is not only the Basinghall-street concern, but another bill will return to Leeds on Tuesday, unless you provide part of the money - get in all unsold goods, whether in your hands or Cleasby's, and let us have a fair start again. The Petershams he wants are ready - I shall be in the City in time to send them out. S. JOHNSON.
To W. Sykes, Esq. September 21.

SIR, - I found myself so unwell this morning I did not go out, and had I gone it would have been eastward and not after you - I complain, as usual, that you act as if you considered it my whole duty and business was to attend on you; you must think I am anxious to know what is going on, and had you stopped five minutes, or gone five yards out of your way, I should not have thought it a great compliment; I got only 7l. from Jack, and was obliged to borrow at three places - I shall be at your house at nine o'clock, as usual. Did Cleasby bring in the cash, as you said he would, for that old black and the cut? if Gasden is to be paid, why not now, while it is so much wanted, and lays by him idle; I hope Thompson's goods are returned as well as Jones' and others, who have them to give an answer - quarter-day is at hand, and the things at Chelsea will be lost. Pray do not start in the morning again and leave me in ignorance - when you are obliged to do so, write.
Another letter was read, in which the prosecutor complained that the defendant was always avoiding him, and giving directions respecting goods.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Seven Years .
NEW COURT. TUESDAY, JANUARY 10.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

463.
SAMUEL JARRETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of December , 1 live tame duck, price 2s. , the property of
John Newson
; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined One Month .

464.
GEORGE STEVENS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of December , 3 pewter pots, value 3s., the goods of
George Parsons
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

THOMAS WOOD
. I live with the Earl of Romney, in York-street, St. James'-square. On the morning of the 10th of December I saw the prisoner near his house - he took from his hat a pewter pint pot, put it under his arm, and then into his pocket - I opened the door, and took him- I sent for Mr. Phelps, who took two pots from the prisoner's pocket, and one from his hat.

GEORGE PARSONS. I keep the Duke of York public-house, in Ormond-yard
. I saw these pots, which are mine, in Mr. Phelps' possession.

WILLIAM PHELPS
. I keep the Red Lion, in York-street. I was sent for, and took these three pots from the prisoner - two were in his pocket, and one in his hat.

GEORGE COLLEY
. I am a Police-constable. I apprehended the prisoner and was present at his trial, for stealing pots, at Guildhall, Westminster, on the 1st of September, 1831 - I have the certificate of his conviction.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Six Months .

465.
ROSS CARNEY
was indicted for
feloniously forging a certain request for the delivery of goods, with intent to defraud
Edward Burry
.

HENRY HOWELL RAGLESS
. I am shopman to Mr. Edward Burry, woollen-draper , Oxford-street
. On the 1st of November the prisoner came between four and five o'clock, produced this written card, and said he came from Mr. Mulford, and wanted five yards and a half of blue cloth to pattern - I got down two pieces, and gave him patterns of them - he went away, returned in about ten minutes, and said Mr. Mulford would have the one at 11s. 6d., but he wished the bill to be made out for 16s, as a gentleman was waiting, and he did not wish him to know the price; I let him have the goods mentioned on this order.
The order being read, was addressed to Mr. Ebury, not Burry.
MR. MULFORD. This is not my writing, and is no resemblance of it.
NOT GUILTY .

466.
ROSS CARNEY
was again
indicted for a like offence .
The order not being correctly set out in the indictment, the prisoner was ACQUITTED .

467.
SUSANNAH SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of December , 8 shirts, value 2l. 10s.; 5 tablecloths, value 15s.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 3s., and 2 spoons, value 12s. , the goods of
Joseph Walker
.

JOSEPH WALKER
. I am an upholsterer , and live in High Holborn
. The prisoner was in my service about three months, and left me on Monday, the 5th of December; I told her about five o'clock, that day, to look up things for the wash; when she had done so I missed her -I searched among the linen, and missed, among others, the articles stated in the indictment, and one silver tablespoon; she came to my house three days afterwards, and I gave her into custody - she delivered the duplicates to the officer.

DAVID FRAIL
. I am in the service of Mr. Aldridge, a pawnbroker, in Orange-street. I have three shirts, a handkerchief, and three table-cloths, pawned at different times by the prisoner; the last was a shirt, on the 14th of November.

HENRY TUACKS
. I am in the service of Mr. Ashdown, a pawnbroker, in Long-acre. I have two shirts, pawned in October; I do not know by whom.

ROBERT WATTS
. I am in the service of Mr. Renton, a pawnbroker, in Holborn. I have some table-cloths, shirts, handkerchiefs, and silver spoons, pawned by the prisoner.

EDWARD MUNDY
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner on the 8th of December, at the prosecutor's; I received the duplicates from her.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 35.

Recommended to Mercy -
Confined Three Months .

468.
JOHN FINLAYSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of January , 18 gallons of brandy, value 27l., the goods of
Thomas Lucy
and another, and then being in a certain boat, in a certain port of entry and discharge, called the port of London .

SECOND COUNT, stating it to be the goods of
Duncan Dunbar
and others.

ALEXANDER LUKE
. I am a constable, stationed at the West India Dock
. On the morning of the 4th of January, before the usual time of opening the gates, the prisoner came to me at the gate, and asked if he could get out; it was then about ten minutes past seven o'clock in the morning - I asked him where he came from; he said from the dock, where he had been all night watching the Princess Vittoria - I said that ship did not want watching; he then said he had been watching a craft alongside of it - I said"What is in it?" he said brandy - I said that was Mr. Lucy's; he said Yes, it was - I asked what he gave him for watching; he said two shillings - he kept shaking, and said he was so cold; I said, "I hope you have not brought any brandy away" - he said No, and took off his hat; I felt a gimblet in his side-pocket, - I then searched him - I found on him a tin tube, a handkerchief tied round his body, and a bladder fastened to it, containing five pints of brandy; I said "you have plundered your charge;" he said "It is only a little drop, take no notice of it;" I said I must, and took him into custody - I went to Mr. Dunbar, who went with me into the boat, called the Charles, by the side of the Princess Vittoria; there were ten pieces of brandy in it - I found a spile in one, the size of the gimlet which I found on the prisoner; I took the brandy to the dock, where it was guaged, and eighteen gallons found to be deficient - I then went on board of the Maria, which also laid along side of the Vittoria, and found some skins of brandy under her head-sheets, and some under her stern-sheets; there were eighteen gallons and a quarter of brandy in all, which seemed to be part of the same quantity.
Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. Did you try the strength of the brandy? A. The revenue-officer did; I think I can tell if there is one degree difference in the strength of brandy.

THOMAS LUCY
. I am in partnership with my brother. The lug boat the Charles belonged to us; she was sent to receive ten puncheons of brandy on account of Mr. Dunbar - it was alongside of the Vittoria, and was to go on board of that vessel; the prisoner was never in our employ, nor appointed to watch that boat - the West India docks are considered a part of the Port of London, by a clause in the last Act, which I have here.

JOSEPH SPARKS ELLIOT
. I am a locker in the Customs. I was at the rum wharf of the West India docks, on the 2nd of January; I guaged ten puncheons of brandy to be shipped on board the Vittoria; No. 29 had one hundred and eleven gallons in it, and No. 33 had one hundred and twelve gallons - I was present on the 4th of January, when they came back to be re-guaged by Mr. Russell, and I chequed them; in No. 29 was a deficiency of nine gallons, and in 33, nine gallons also; they had been in the lug boat, by the side of the Vittoria.
Cross-examined. Q. Were they of the same quality as near as could be? A. There might be two or three tenths difference in the strength.

JOHN WILLIAM RUSSELL
. I am a guager in the Customs. On the 4th of January I guaged No. 33, and on the day following No. 29; there was a deficiency of nine gallons in each; I tried the brandy found in the skin, and that taken from the bulk, there appeared a difference of about 1 1/2 per cent. between that and the bulk - the shifting it from vessel to vessel would account for that; I have known it lose 2 per cent., by racking and by evaporation.

Cross-examined. Q. In drawing it off it is exposed to the air? A. Yes, and I imagine that it will lose strength by that; there might be some exposure to the air if it passed through the tube - it might not be a close fit, or the bladder might not be closed tight.

JOSEPH JONES
. I went on board the boat, and saw the plug-holes.

JOHN FOY
. I am principal of the Police at the docks. On the morning of the 4th of January Luke brought the prisoner to my office; I made him no promise or threat -I asked where he got it from; he said he had it from a craft of brandy he had been watching for Mr. Lucy, in the Export-dock, along side the Princes Vittoria; I asked if he had any more - he said he had not, that he was going to take it home, and no other person had been concerned with him; I suspected that more might have been extracted, - I desired Luke to make a search, and they produced in all, eighteen gallons and a quarter, in eleven bladders.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you sure he said it was his own doing? A. Yes, he persisted for four or five hours in the same story; a person could take that quantity of liquor out of the vessels, but such a thing has not occurred for a length of time, as it is very difficult to do it.
GUILTY of stealing five pints only . Aged 35.
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

469.
ANN SMITH
and
ELIZA ROBERTS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of December , 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 watch-key, value 1d., and 1 book, value 1s., the goods of
John Cronk
, from his person .

JOHN CRONK. I am a broker , and live in Bartholomew-close. On the 19th of December, between eight and nine o'clock, I went to Whitecross-street, and in turning into Beech-street, to go home, I saw several girls; the prisoners were among them - they took hold of my arms, one on each side; I was not quite sober, but had all my faculties about me - they said I should walk with them; I said I had no money to treat them - they said that made no difference; I had my watch and pocket book with me, and I am quite sure they were safe when they took hold of me- I had felt them just before; they took me to Golden-lane, and then to Blue Anchor-alley
, when they tried to drag me up a dark alley; I became frightened, as I thought they were going to get me burked - I struggled to get away; they scuffled with me, and took my watch and my pocket-book - I did not feel them taken, but I missed them, and accused them of it; Smith ran away immediately - I took hold of Roberts; I sent for an officer, and gave Roberts in charge - I described Smith, and she was taken.

ROWLAND SWAN
. I am a serjeant of Police. A boy came for me; I saw the prosecutor, who said he had been robbed of his watch and pocket-book - I took charge of Roberts, and found Smith in King's-court, about thirty or forty yards off; she had run into a house - I went up two pairs of stairs, at No. 6, and found her sitting by the fire; I found the watch in the court close by the door she ran into.

HENRY COLEY
. I am a Policeman. The two prisoners were brought to the station-house, and put into the cell; I heard Roberts ask Smith what sort of a plant she had made - Smith said an excellent good one, that she had run up the court, planted the watch under the balustrades, and covered it over with dirt - the book she have in the house, then run up stairs, and asked the woman whether she took in caps to wash, and said there was something lost in the court - that she ran in for fear of being taken, and threw her bonnet off, that she might appear as if she lived there.
Smith. The Magistrate asked him how he could swear to my voice, when there were others in the cell. Witness. There was no one in when they were talking.

WILLIAM CURTIS
. I am a shoemaker, and live in King's-court. I heard a disturbance, and went down stairs; I kicked against this book, and took it to my father, who took it to the station - Smith had passed the place.

ANN GRIFFITHS
. I live in King's-court - my husband is a butcher. On the night the watch was stolen Smith rushed into my room, which is up two pairs of stairs - she was quite a stranger; she said, "Mistress, for God's sake, don't say any thing - there is something lost, and I am afraid I shall be taken up;" I went down stairs, and left her standing in the room - I went up just afterwards, with the Policeman, and saw her sitting by the fire, with her bonnet off.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Roberts' Defence. I met this young woman - she asked me to go to a person who used to wash caps for her; we went on, and met this gentleman - he asked if we would take him home; he said he had no money, but he wouldsee where we lived, and call another day - Smith then went up the court; he took hold of me, and said I had robbed him.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

ROBERTS -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

470.
JOHN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of December , 2 saws, value 15s.; 3 planes, value 14s., and 1 screw-driver, value 1s., the goods of John Lane; and 1 saw, value 1s. 6d.; 4 planes, value 26s.; 1 rule, value 1s.; 3 punches, value 3d.; 2 chisels, value 6d.; 2 gimblets, value 2d.; 1 bradawl, value 1d., and 1 pair of compasses, value 3d , the goods of
William Bugdon
.

DANIEL KALLER
. I am a labourer. On the 16th of December I was working on Mr. Cubitt's premises, in St. Pancras
- the men who lost their tools were at work for him; they went to dinner, and I staid there - I saw two men coming out of the premises, a little after twelve o'clock, and getting over the fence which is round the enclosed ground; the prisoner got over, and the other man handed the basket of tools to him over the fence - the prisoner took it; I caught him about four hundred yards from the premises - the other man got away.

GEORGE TAYLOR
. I am a Policeman. The prisoner and these tools were given into my custody.

JOHN LANE
. I was at work on these premises. I went to dinner, left my tools, and William Bugdon did the same - they are all here; I know his tools and mine.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Seven Years .

471.
JAMES SHEFFIELD
was
indicted for embezzlement .

GEORGE PROCTER
. I am a plumber - the prisoner was my errand-boy ; he conducted himself well - he received money on my account. On the 20th of December I was in the King's Bench, and sent him to
Rachael Saxon
, to receive 2l. 15s.; I never received any part of it; I was in the Fleet, and sent him from the Fleet for it - I went there on the 6th of November, but I kept my establishment up as well as I could.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you in the King's Bench or the Fleet? A. The Fleet - I have had no quarrel with the prisoner; I have had his sister in prison for robbing me - she was tried in this Court, I believe, two Sessions ago; she was a servant of mine - I have no wife - the prisoner did not sleep at my house while I was in confinement, nor for two or three months before; he had slept at my house, in the same room as I did - there was one bed in that room, but occasionally there was one made for him; his sister slept with me.
NOT GUILTY .

472.
ELIZABETH PICKETT
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 3rd of December , 2 caps, value 5s.; 1 collar, value 20s.; 7 yards of net, value 1s.; 2 nightcaps, value 5s.; 15 yards of lace, value 70s.; 1 pair of stays, value 30s.; 7 shifts, value 30s.; 2 petticoats, value 7s.; 1 pair of drawers, value 6d.; 3 pairs of stockings, value 3s.; 1 pair of socks, value 9d.; 2 night-gowns, value 2s.; 6 napkins, value 6s.; 6 cravats, value 9s.; 1 table-cloth, value 1s.; 1 bag, value 1d.; 1 pillow-case, value 6d.; 1 towel, value 1s.; 4 cloths, value 3s.; 1 pinafore, value 1s.; 1 jacket, value 1s., and 1 shirt, value 1s., the goods of
Henry Watson
, well knowing them to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

HENRY WATSON
. I live just by Southgate - my wife takes in washing. On Wednesday, the 30th of November, I went to bed about eight o'clock, and saw the linen in a basket and two tubs, partly wet and partly dry - some of it was in water; I was alarmed at two o'clock in the morning - I came down, and found the house broken open, and all the linen gone, both wet and dry.

ELIZABETH WATSON
. I am the prosecutor's wife. On the night of the 30th of November I had a great quantity of linen to wash, and some of my own; there was a quantity of wet linen in the basket, which I and my daughter had washed through that day, and there was some in water- among them were the articles stated in the indictment; they are now here; they were washed, ready to go home the next day - when I got up the next morning the linen was all gone; the window had been taken quite out - the linen was marked when I lost it, but when I saw it again some of the marks were picked out, and some cut off.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Whose property is it? A. Mr. Jones', Mr. Butler's, Mr. Bright's, and Mr. Salisbury's.
COURT. Q. We understand the washing was completed? A. Yes, they had only to be dried and ironed.

JOHN CAMP
. I am a constable of Edmonton. I got a warrant to search the prisoner's house, in Claret-street, Edmonton. Mead found most of the property in the house - I stood against the door, and saw him go into the front room, take a pair of stays from the fire, and say,"This is what I am looking for."
Cross-examined. Q. How was the door of the house? A. It was open, and the prisoner stood against it, looking out - I went in directly.

JOHN MEAD
. I am constable of Enfield. I went on the 3rd of December to search the house with Camp - I went into the front room, and found this pair of stays, hanging by the fire drying - I asked the prisoner who they belonged to; she said, "They are mine;" I said, "Then you are my prisoner;" I searched the house all over - I found the flooring, at the bottom of the house, was hollow; it is raised six or seven inches - I opened a door under the stairs, and put a stick under the floor; I felt something there - I then laid down, and dragged these articles out in this bag, which was nearly full: these are the articles - some of them have had the marks picked out, and some cut off; I found this cloth full of articles besides.

Q. Was there any wash-house? A. I do not remember any; there is only one room up stairs, and one down; I think I saw two children in bed; a man, she cohabited with, came out as I went in - I will not swear that she was not at the next house.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

BENJAMIN AYLIN
. I was with Mead, and went round the house to prevent any one from escaping - there were four shifts, nine towels, and several other things hanging round the room on a line, and several things were found up stairs, on a second search.
Cross-examined. Q. Could not any one, who entered the house, have seen these things on the line? A. Yes.

HENRY JOHN SAWYER
. I acted as clerk to the Magistrate at the examination of the prisoner, and I saw her make her mark to this deposition, which was read to her -(read.)

"The linen found in my house by the constable was brought to my house to wash by two men whom I knew by sight, but I did not know their names; I am a widow - I rent the house in which I reside, and no person lives with me but my children; the men, on leaving the linen, said they would fetch them on the following Saturday; they brought them on Friday night, the 2nd, and I was apprehended on Saturday morning.

GUILTY . Aged 27. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

473.
ELIZABETH LIDDELL
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 3rd of December , 5 cravats, value 5s.; 2 shifts, value 4s.; 1 pillow-case, value 6d.; 3 glass-cloths, value 6d.; part of a table-cloth, value 6d., and part of 2 shifts, value 6s., the goods of
Henry Watson
, well knowing them to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

ELIZABETH WATSON
. I am the wife of
Henry Watson
Our house was broken open on the night of the 30th of November - the property that was found at the last prisoner'swasnotall I lost; I have seen some other things since, and the marks have been cut out and picked out of them, the same as the others; it was taken from my house by burglary.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Whether the marks were taken out by the person who stole these things you cannot tell? A. No.

JOHN MEAD
. I am constable of Enfield. I went to the prisoner's house on the 3rd of December - I found a great quantity of linen there; this is it - here are five cravats and other things; Mrs. Watson has selected some part of it, which she knows; some of it was in the washtub, some on the backs of chairs, and some on the washingform; there are from thirty to forty articles in all.
Cross-examined. Q. Were they in the room into which the street door leads? A. Yes; the house is in a court, and as soon as I opened the door, these things were there.

JOSEPH FORSTER
. I am a constable. I was present at the search of the prisoner's house: I found this top of a lady's shift in an old saucepan, by the side of the fire, covered with water; it forms a whole shift with this other part, found by Mead.

MRS. WATSON. This shift is one of the articles lost from my husband's house; it belongs to Mrs. Jones, of Hackney- it had her name on it, but it has been picked out - it was whole when I lost it; here is a table-cloth torn in half - it was whole when I lost it; here are some glass-cloths, with the name cut off.
Prisoner's Defence. It was brought to my house just as it is - I did nothing to it.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Transported for 14 years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

474.
ANN WALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of December , 2 pairs of gloves, value 3s. , the goods of
John Crawley
.

HENRY WINDER. I am in the service of Mr.
John Crawley
, a silk-mercer , in Oxford-street
. On the 10th of December the prisoner came into his shop; a lady had just bought a pair of gloves - I put them into a piece of paper for her, and the lady complained that they were gone; the prisoner was near the place where I had put the gloves, and I saw a bit of the paper under her shawl - I accused her of having them; she said they were things she had bought - I took them, and found they were the gloves which I had sold the lady; the prisoner had not bought any thing - we told her we should charge an officer with her; she said "Do," or else we should have let her go - she offered to pay for the gloves.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you see her searched? A. I did, and no property of ours was found on her; she said she had picked them off the floor- the lady had paid 3s. 4d. for the gloves, and I delivered them to her.
Prisoner. I begged him to let me go.
NOT GUILTY .

475.
JAMES RUSSELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of December , 2 live tame fowls, price 4s. , the property of
Robert Lill De Burgh
.

JAMES STONE
. I am gamekeeper to Mr. De Burgh; he keeps fancy fowls. On the 24th of December I saw them all safe in the pheasant-house about three o'clock in the afternoon; it was then dark - I went again on Sunday, the 25th, before day-light, and as soon as it was light I missed six fowls - these are two of them; I have no doubt the persons had got up one side of the pheasantry, and got in at the roof - the prisoner is a labourer , and lived at Harmondsworth, about two miles off.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Was it not dark when you left them on Saturday? A. Yes; they went to roost early - there was a place for the fowls to get out at, but I could see a man's footstep inside; I was standing just outside the door when the constable and my master found these fowls dead in the prisoner's bed - I do not know whether the house belongs to him or his mother, but he slept there.

JAMES BAKER
. I am constable of Harmondsworth. On the day after Christmas-day I went to the house; I have known the prisoner ever since he was a boy - he was over at the public-house; I told him he must go along with me, I had a warrant to search his house; he said he had not the key of the house - I said, "But the place where you sleep" - he said he could get in there; he took the key, and opened the door - Mr. De Burgh told me to stand at the door while he got a light; he then told me to go in and search the place while he stood at the door - I went in; the bed was just by the door - I found in it these two fowls, which I brought out, and gave to Mr. De Burgh.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you not know that the place belonged to his father and mother? A. The house belongs to his mother - his father is dead.

THE REV . ROBERT LILL DE BURGH. These are my fowls - they are pheasant bantains; there are none such within fifteen miles of my place - the keeper gave me information. I went and found them at the prisoner's as stated; his mother lives as housekeeper to a man - these were not found in her house, but a barn adjoining, which is the prisoner's own.

Cross-examined. Q. Will you undertake to swear that the woman never goes into the residence of her son? A. I do not know who pays the rent, but I know that the barn is to all intents and purposes the son's residence, and he confessed to me that it was his residence - I do not know that he is a poacher; I do not believe he ever took any of my game.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

476.
JOHN WALKER
was indicted for
stealing on the 15th of December , 4 loaves of bread, value 1s. 4d. , the goods of
George Dowsett
.

GEORGE DOWSETT. I keep a chandler-shop , in Rahere-street, St. Luke's
. On the 15th of December, about two o'clock in the day, I was watching, and saw the prisoner and three others; another boy took four loaves out of my window; the prisoner stood next to him, and took the loaves of him - they were together - the prisoner ran away - I pursued him; he threw down the loaves just before I took hold of him - I had not lost sight of him.
WILLIAM LEWIS. Mr. Dowsett gave me the loaves, and I took them to the station.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

477.
THOMAS WARREN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of December , 1 leopard skin, value 30s., and 1 handkerchief, value 2s. , the goods of
Margaret Walters
.

MARGARET WALTERS
. I live in Long-lane
. This leopard skin and handkerchief are mine, and had been in a drawer in my kitchen - the prisoner lodged in the house.

THOMAS THOMAS
. I am a Police-constable. In consequence of information I went to a furrier's shop, on the 12th of December, the prisoner was standing at the door, and his son was inside offering this skin for sale, at a very low price - I went in and took him; he did not hear what I said to the boy - I took him to the station, and from what he said, I went and took the prisoner to the station; I questioned him, and he said it was given to him by a young man named Watson, in Long-lane, to sell.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. She said, "Let me put this skin into the drawer, and the Captain shall never have it any more;" this passed on for a month, and one Sunday, John Watson came to the door, and I let him in - he said "Is Margaret up?" I said Yes; she came to him and said, "How did you leave Henry?" he said, "In good spirits;" she said "I have the skin, do you think he will ask for it when he comes home" he said No; then said she "I will have it sold, and divide the money between us," and they gave it to me to sell.
MARGARET WALTERS. That is not true - it was given to me by Captain Monro; I had shown it to the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 53. -
Confined Two Months .

478.
SUSAN WHITELOCK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of December , 4 pairs of clogs, value 4s. , the goods of
Nathan Blake
.

NATHAN BLAKE
. I keep a shoe-shop in Edgware-road
. I lost these clogs on the 31st of December, but I did not see them taken; I had missed them about half an hour before the Police-constable brought them.

CHARLES CLARK
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner about two hundred yards from the prosecutor's house. I found three pairs of clogs and an odd one on her, but she struggled very much, and I think we lost one.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. It was want made me do it - I have not a friend in the world.

GUILTY. Aged 17. -
Judgment Respited
.

479.
JOHN WILLIAMS
and
BENJAMIN THOMAS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of December , 7 half-crowns and 4 shillings, the monies of
James Gadsby
, from his person .

JAMES GADSBY
. On Christmas morning I was drunk, and the Policeman put me into the watch-house; I then had seven half-crowns and four shillings - I am sure of that; I was sober enough to remember that when I was put in the cell I had the money - I fell asleep, and when I awoke I found the two prisoners by me; I believe I was put in there about half-past twelve o'clock on Saturday night - I staid till about nine on Sunday morning, and when I went up I missed all my money.

THOMAS FARRANT
, I am a Policeman. I had taken the two prisoners at eight o'clock on the Saturday night, for attempting to pick pockets - I put them into the cell, but before that I searched them minutely, and on Thomas I found two handkerchiefs, a sixpence, and 1 1/2d., and on Williams, a sixpence, a halfpenny, a farthing, and one handkerchief - this was before Gadsby was brought in there, as I understood, but I did not see him that night.

WILLIAM TRODD
. I was on duty in St. James' watch-house
. I saw the prisoners brought in - they were searched, and what has been stated was found on them in my presence; I put them into the cell, and when the prosecutor was brought in, I put him into the cell - when he came out he complained of having been robbed - I called the prisoners, and searched them; I found on Thomas four half-crowns, three shillings, and this box, and on Williams three half-crowns and one shilling - I had seen the money in the prosecutor's tobacco-box the night before, but I did not count it.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Had you not seen this box on the prisoners the night before? A. Yes - I do not know whether any of the prisoners' friends had been there; the prosecutor was not so drunk but that he knew what he was doing, or he could not have taken his money out and shown it to me.
JAMES GADSBY. I believe this to be my money.
Cross-examined. Q. Where did you receive it? A. I had taken it; there were twelve or fourteen persons in the cell.
Williams' Defence. It was money my master had paid me on Saturday night.
Thomas put in a written Defence, stating that the money found on him was his own, and that he had it in a box, which was not opened when he was searched.

WILLIAMS -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

THOMAS -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

480.
ALFRED WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 1 watch, value 2l. 10s., the goods of
James Walker
; and that he had been previously convicted of felony .

JAMES WALKER
. I lodged in Edward-street, Soho
- I am a tailor . The prisoner lodged in the same room, and in the same bed; he called himself a tailor - in August last I missed a watch; I believe I had put it on the bedside, or by the window, when I went to bed on the Monday evening - on Tuesday morning I got up, and dressed myself; I looked to see what o'clock it was, and left my watch in the same place - I went for some rolls, and went into the sitting-room, to breakfast; the prisoner came down, and said, "Good morning;" my landlord said, "Do you call this morning?" (it was then past nine o'clock) we went on with our breakfast, and in about ten minutes I went into the bed-room, and missed my watch; I afterwards found my watch at a pawnbroker's, in Charlotte-place, Lambethmarsh - I searched for the prisoner for a month, but could not find him; his week was not up at the lodging, and he ought to have returned - when three months had expired, I was in great want of my watch; I redeemed it for 2l. 4s. 8d. - I never found the prisoner till last Friday week; when I saw him he said, "You have compounded felony;" I said, "For what?" he repeated it again - I said, "For what?" he then said he took the watch through distress.

GEORGE COOPER
. I went to inquire at the prisoner's lodgings for a man he knew, and from some inquiry I thought he was the man who robbed the prosecutor, and took him.

JOSEPH CLEMENTS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner - I made him no promise or threat; he admitted that he took the watch.
-. I am an officer. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction - I am certain he is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

481.
GEORGE BAILEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of December , 2 garden hand-glasses, value 3s. , the goods of
James Young
.

JAMES YOUNG. I lost two garden hand-glasses from my garden, at Middleton-hill, Spa-fields
, on the 17th of December, and from information I found I had lost another - I do not know the prisoner.

GEORGE PEARSON
. I am a gardener, and live in George-street, Bagnigge-wells. I bought these two glasses of the prisoner on the 21st of December - I had seen him once or twice before; he asked me to buy them- I said I would not buy them of a stranger, I would come and look at them, and he took me to his garden, where there was a summer-house, locked up; I bought some things of him then; he brought the glasses afterwards, and left them at my neighbour's - he called the next day, and I bought them of him for 9s. 6d.

WILLIAM REYNOLDS
. I received the prisoner in charge- I have known him seven years; he has had a good character.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 24.

Recommended to Mercy -
Confined Fourteen Days .

482.
WILLIAM FIELD
and
JOHN JONES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of December , 1 coat, value 20s., the goods of
Samuel Jones
; and that the said
John Jones
had been before convicted of felony .

SAMUEL JONES
. I drive for Mr. Norris, of Sion-hill, my waggon was in Marylebone-street
on the 8th of December - I was unloading some potatoes, and my coat was on the waggon; I did not take any notice of the prisoners, but they might have been there; the officer brought me my coat - this is it.

FRANCIS KEYS
. I am an officer. On the 8th of December I was coming along Great Marylebone-street - I saw the waggon, and the coat on the sacks of potatoes; I saw the prisoners pass, and look at it - I hid myself, saw Field get on the wheel of the waggon, take the coat, and give it to Jones; they ran one way - I pursued, ran past Field, and took Jones with the coat; a man came up, and I told him to take Field, which he did.

PETER HOGG
. I caught Field in Queen Anne-street- he was running.

ROBERT GOOSE
. I am a Policeman. I have a certificate of the conviction of Jones, by the name of Bland, in September last, which I got from Mr. Clark's office; I was a witness, and know he is the man.

FIELD -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

483.
ELIZA FRENCH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of December , 1 gown, value 2s. , the goods of
Ambrose Rotton
.

AMBROSE ROTTON. I live in Playhouse-yard
. On the 20th of December the prisoner came to my house, but I was not at home; on the 30th she came again - I was sitting in my back parlour; my son came in, and said the girl who had taken the gown on the 20th was in the shop.

EDWARD ROTTON
. I am the prosecutor's son. On the 20th of December the prisoner came to my father's shop, and asked for an old shoe; I had not one that would suit her - she asked if I should have one the next day; I said most likely - she said she would call again; I went round the counter after she was gone, and found a pair of trousers pulled down; I took them up, and then missed a gown, which had been safe a quarter of an hour before; I have not seen it since.
NOT GUILTY .

484.
EDWARD DRAYTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of December , 2 loaves of bread, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Amos Butts
.

AMOS BUTTS
. I am a baker , at Endfield
. On the 26th of December I saw the prisoner come and take two loaves off the counter; I knew him before by sight, but not by name; he has been on the parish lately - he was walking away with the bread; I collared him at the door, and he dropped it.

HENRY BROCKENBOROUGH
. I saw the prisoner take the loaves off the counter, and my master took him directly.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Confined Three Months .

485.
HANNAH GADSBY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of January , 2 sheets, value 4s, and 1 counterpane, value 2s. , the goods of
Ann Cowell
.

ANN COWELL. On Monday, the 2nd of January, the prisoner hired a furnished room of me; a soldier took the room with her for a week, and they said they wanted clean sheets - I put them clean sheets; the soldier gave me 1s. earnest, and said the prisoner was his wife - the next morning they went out, and never returned; they left the door wide open - I fetched a Policeman, and missed two sheets, and the counterpane, which were let to them; I had the soldier apprehended the next morning.

HENRY KEAN EDWARD NEWSTEAD
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Tothill-street. I took in a sheet and a quilt from a woman, on the 3rd of January.

JAMES STANTON
, I live at Mr. Morritt's - I have a sheet, pawned by the prisoner, on the 3rd of January.

GEORGE PECK
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner; she gave me these duplicates of the sheet and counterpane.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I slept there the next night.

ANN COWELL
. She never came back to my knowledge.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

486.
DANIEL JONES
and
JOHN PEDDRICK
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of December , 1 shirt, value 3s. , the goods of
Timothy White
.

ELIZABETH WHITE
. I am the wife of
Timothy White
, and live in York-street, Kingsland-road
. On the 14th of December I hung some things out to dry, and among them some shirts; I missed one of them.

CHARLES BENFIELD
. I keep cows, and live three doors from White's. I had seen the two prisoners within four or five yards of her garden; they were both together, and I told Waller of them.

CHARLES WALLER
. I am a Policeman. Benfield gave me information, and I took the prisoners; I found this shirt in Peddrick's jacket - he said he had picked it up.
Jones' Defence. Peddrick told me he had picked up a shirt, and the officer took us into custody.
Peddrick's Defence. I was going along, and picked it up.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

PEDDRICK -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Three Months .

487.
WILLIAM LUCKER
was
indicted for embezzlement .

SOPHIA SUSANNAH BYFIELD
. I am the wife of
Thomas Richard Byfield
; we are chimney-sweeper
s. The prisoner was in our employ - he had to receive money on our account.

ELIZABETH MILLS
. I live in Arlington-street
. I paid the prisoner 1s. 6d. for sweeping a chimney on the 24th of December: he did not give me a receipt then, but he generally did.

RICHARD DAWSON
. I paid the prisoner 1s. 6d. for sweeping my father's chimney on the 24th of December.
MRS. BYFIELD. He never accounted to me for these sums; he said Mrs. Mills would pay on a future day, when she wanted some more done.
Prisoner's Defence. My mistress came to me, and asked me to go back and work the money out. Witness. Yes, I said he might come back and get my husband's money.
NOT GUILTY .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

488.
MARY MORGAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of December , 10 handkerchiefs, value 5s. , the goods of
Henry Davis
.

GEORGE BALLINGER
, I am shopman to Mr. Henry Davis, a hosier , in Oxford-street
. On the 8th of December a man came into the shop, and in consequence of what he said. I went out and took the prisoner about fifteen yards off - I took her back, put my hand under her shawl, and found these ten handkerchiefs of my master's; she acknowledged her guilt, and asked forgiveness.
Prisoner. I was in distress.

GUILTY . Aged 46. -
Confined Ten Days .

489.
JAMES OLIVER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of November , 1 bedstead, value 10s. , the goods of
Thomas Ridge
.

ANN RIDGE
. I am the wife of
Thomas Ridge
- we live in Cumberland-street, Middlesex-hospital
. On the 29th of November, between five and six o'clock in the evening, I lost a bedstead; I had seen it safe half an hour before - they left one leg behind, and the broker had one made.

JOHN PARROTT
. I am a broker, and live in Queen-street, Seven-dials. On the evening of the 29th of November, the prisoner came to my shop with another young man, who carried a bedstead; the prisoner said he had a bedstead for sale, and asked if I would buy it - he asked 3s. 6d. for it; I offered him 3s. - he went away, came back again, and said if I would stand a quartern of gin I should have it for 3s. - I gave him the 3s.; we all three then went to a public-house, and had the gin - the prisoner afterwards came with an iron pot; I gave him into custody - he said his father bought the bedstead for him six months before; it wanted a leg - I did not know him before.

CHARLES PARROTT
. I live with my father. I remember the prisoner bringing this bedstead.

THOMAS MADAM
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the broker in my life till last Saturday month, when he gave me into custody.

GUILTY . Aged 18 -
Transported for Seven Years .

490.
CATHERINE POWER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of December , 2 shirts, value 2s., the goods of
Leonard Clare Matthews
and another .

THOMAS BLUETT
. I am a shopman to Leonard Clare Matthews and his father, pawnbroker s, Whitecross-street
. On the evening of the 9th of December the prisoner came to take two articles out of pawn - I gave her one, which she paid for, and waited for the other; she was looking at some handkerchiefs, and I saw her unpin a cotton shirt, and conceal it about her person - I sent for a Policeman, who found the shirt on the floor near her, and in going to the station-house this flannel shirt was picked up, which Iknow to be my master's - it had hung near the other; I had seen it a few minutes before: I saw her with the cotton shirt in her hand - she was rolling it up under her gown.
JURY. Q. How many persons were in the shop? A. No one but her; when she unpinned the shirt she was asking the price of a handkerchief, and her back was towards me.

GEORGE AVERY
. I am a Policeman. I found the prisoner in the shop; this cotton shirt was at her feet - she denied all knowledge of it, but on her way to the station-house she said she had picked it up on the floor, and she thought it belonged to a customer; on our way through Lamb's-passage she said she wanted to stop, and when we got to the station Dosson brought in this flannel shirt - Bluett brought in a rule and a sixpence - I had seen the sixpence on the counter - she refused to take it, and insisted upon having her other article.

GEORGE DOSSON
. I am a Policeman. I saw the prisoner in Lamb's-passage - I saw her drop this flannel shirt - I am confident it fell from her; I took it up.
JURY. Q. How far is that from the station? A. About a hundred yards; I took it up, and walked after them - the officer did not know I had it.

Prisoner's Defence. There was Mr. Matthews' brother, Bluett, and a boy in the shop, when I first went; I was the last person served - I put down the money for the other article, which he could not find, and said I would call in the morning; he returned me the money in the watch-house, and the ticket - I found the cotton shirt under my feet at the back door; I thought it belonged to a customer - I never saw the flannel shirt till I got to the watch-house; they did not see it fall from me - I had no apron on.
GEORGE DOSSON. I saw it fall from her, and I took it up.

COURT to BLUETT. Q. Did you see her unpin the shirt? A. Yes, I did; there were no customers in the shop but her - she had an apron on, and a red cotton gown; I did not charge her with it till I sent for the officer.
JURY to AVERY. Q. Was her gown open in front? A. Certainly not - she had an apron on, I am certain, for I took it into the cell to her when she was locked up.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Confined Seven Days .

491.
WILLIAM PULLEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of December , 1 child's chaise, value 12s. , the goods of
Thomas Cleghorn
.

ELIZABETH CLEGHORN
. I am the wife of
Thomas Cleghorn
. I missed a child's four-wheel'd chaise on the 7th of December.

WILLIAM VANN
. I was in my shop on the 9th of December; I saw the prisoner with this chaise in his hand, offering it for sale to Marchant, at her door, but she is not here, and I could not hear what he said.
NOT GUILTY .

492.
WILLIAM REED
and
JOHN TAYLOR
were indicted for
stealing 16lbs. of copper, value 20s., the goods of
George Matthew Hoare
and another .
The copper being fixed to a building, the prisoners were
ACQUITTED .

493.
JOSEPH CARTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of January , 1 pair of trousers, value 16s. , the goods of
William David Ray
.

PATRICK MANNING. I am the son of
John Manning
, of Adam and Eve-court, Whitecross-street. On the afternoon of the 4th of January I was by the Flying Horse, in Crown-street
- I saw the prisoner near Mr. Ray's shop; he took the trousers off the iron rail, and ran away with them - I ran and overtook him, without losing sight of him - a woman picked up the trousers.

WILLIAM LOVELACE
. I live in Long-alley. I was coming up Long-alley, and saw the prisoner running - I stopped him; an officer came up, and took him.
Prisoner. Q. Was no one running before me? A. No.

THOMAS HOWARD
. I am foreman to William
David Ray
- he is a clothes-saleman. I was standing in the corner of the shop - I saw the rails shake, and the trousers move; I went out, and was told which way the prisoner had gone - I pursued, and saw him running with something - I saw him stopped, and Maxey brought in these trousers; one of the prisoner's companious took the pin out of them.

SARAH MAXEY
. I picked up these trousers, three or four doors from where the prisoner was stopped; I had seen him running with something, but could not see what.(Property produced and sworn to.)

MICHAEL COCKLIN
. I saw the prisoner run, and drop these trousers.

CHARLES RICKETTS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and have had the trousers ever since.
Prisoner. I was in great distress.
GUILTY. Aged 18.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury.

Judgment Respited
.

494.
WILLIAM SHARPE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of December , 1 jacket, value 1s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 1s., the goods of
Joseph Bennett
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

MARY FREEMAN
. I am servant to Mr. Fry, of Seymour-house, Seymour-place, Little Chelsea
. On the 19th of December I saw the prisoner take from a chair in the hall a suit of clothes, but he dropped the waistcoat - I ran after him; I saw him throw this coat and trousers over a gentleman's premises - I got a neighbour to assist me, and he took the prisoner, without my losing sight of him; these are the articles - they belong to
Joseph Bennett
.

WILLIAM WILKINSON
. I am a tailor, and live in Seymour-row; I heard Stop thief! called, and saw the prisoner running - I followed him into an empty house, in Walnut-treewalk, where I took him - Freeman went to the door of the house, but did not go in.

JOHN PURDY
. I am a Policeman. I received the prisoner into custody.

GEORGE PECK
. I am a Police-constable. I was present here on the 12th of May, 1831, and saw the prisoner tried - I have a certificate of his conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Six Months .

495.
JOSEPH ROBERTS
and
JEREMIAH WILLIAMS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of January , 1 pair of boots, value 6s., and two pairs of shoes, value 6s. , the goods of
James Baldwin
.

JOHN MINTON
. I live in York-place, Islington. On the4th of January I was passing Mr. Baldwin's shop, between five and six o'clock, and saw the prisoners talking to each other - I passed on, and as I returned I saw Roberts in the shop, near the counter; Williams was beckoning him out- he came out with two pairs of shoes and a pair of boots; I followed him; he threw them down; I took him back to the shop, and heard him beg the gentleman's pardon - Williams made his escape at that time, but when we went to Hatton-garden he followed us from the watch-house; I went out, and took him - I suppose he had followed us a mile.

THOMAS LAYLER
. I am apprentice to Mr. Minton. I was opposite Mr. Baldwin's - a person took up the boots and shoes, and gave them to me; I took them to the shop, and then to the watch-house.

THOMAS MEADOWS
. I am a Policeman. Roberts was brought to the watch-house, with these boots and shoes - Williams followed to the office, and was taken.

JAMES BALDWIN. I keep the shop in Upper-street
. I was in my room, behind the shop, and saw a boy run out; I went to the door, and pursued another boy
, who got away - when I got back these boots and shoes had been brought back; they are mine, and were safe in the window, before I saw the boy in the shop.
Robert's Defence. I know nothing of them.
Williams' Defence. I saw the prisoner going to the office, and followed.

ROBERTS -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

WILLIAMS -
NOT GUILTY .

496.
JOHN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of January , 1 pair of trousers, value 20s. , the goods of
George King
.

GEORGE KING
. I keep a sale-shop , in St. Marylebone-street
. On the night of the 5th of January I was in the back of my shop, and saw a person's hand inside my shop door; it had hold of one of the legs of a pair of trousers, which were hanging inside my shop - I saw them pulled down; I went to the door, and saw no one near but the prisoner; I followed, and took hold of him - I found under his arm the trousers; he said, "I am very glad you have taken me; I am very much distressed, and wished to be transported."

JOHN HARDY
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner- he said he was glad he was taken, and wanted to be transported.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

497.
MARY ANNE SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of January , 4 handkerchiefs, value 16s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 6s., and 12 yards of ribbon, value 16s. , the goods of
Samuel Strong
and
Richard Woolley
.

CHARLES SCOTT. I am in the service of Messrs. Strong and Woolley - they are silk-mercer
s. On the 3rd of January, about noon, the prisoner came to their shop - she purchased a number of articles, which came to 4l. 13s.; she desired them to be sent to a direction which she gave; I mentioned it to Mr. Woolley, who followed her.

RICHARD WOOLLEY
. I am in partnership with Mr. Samuel Strong. On the 3rd of January I followed the prisoner to her lodgings, in Peter-street, Cow-cross - I first saw her on the stairs; I got her to come down, and sent the boy for an officer - she denied any knowledge of me, but I told her she had been in my shop a short time before, and if she would give up what property she had of mine, I would suspend the charge, if the constable would; she then took me up stairs to her room, and gave me two silk handkerchiefs out of her bed, which was turned up; I said she must have some ribbon - she then produced this ribbon; the officer then came, and he found these other handkerchiefs and stockings in the bed.(Property produced and sworn to.)

RICHARD MILLEN
. I am an officer. I found these handkerchiefs and stockings doubled up in the bed; this ribbon and these other handkerchiefs the prosecutor had in his hand.
JURY. Q. Did any one else occupy that room? A. The person who let the room said it was let to the prisoner only.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, pleading poverty, and expressing her contrition.
GUILTY. Aged 22.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury . -
Confined 1 Month .

498.
JOHN SIBLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of October , 1 goose, value 4s. , the property of
Thomas Payne
.

SARAH PAYNE
. I am the wife of Thomas Payne. On the night of the 22nd of October, we lost three geese, one was brought back by the officer - I knew it was one we had lost.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long was that after you missed it? A. I saw it safe on the Saturday night, and the officer showed it me again on the Sunday night; it was then dead; it was alive when I saw it on the Saturday - the head and wing of it are here.
COURT. Q. Was the place in which the geese were, broken? A. Yes, the staple was drawn.

MARK WALSH
. I am an officer of South-mimms. I received information, and went to Mr. Bull's, who keeps an eating-house at Hadley, on the 23rd of October, about half-past six o'clock in the evening, I found a goose dead, but quite warm - I showed it to Mr. Pitman, and then Mr. Paine; they claimed it: there were some marks of blood on the back of the neck, but none on the prisoner when I took him.

JOSEPH BULL
. I live at Hadley. On the 23rd of October the prisoner came to my house, about half-past one o'clock; he asked what I had done with my ducks - I said I had got rid of some, and some persons had got rid of some for me; he then asked how geese were - I said they were too dear for me; he said he knew where there were some to be had cheap - I said I supposed on the cross - he said No, it was all right, that he had them from a person he had been ditching for; I said I had no goose money - he paid for what he had, and went away: he came again in about an hour, with a goose in a sack, and asked if he could leave it there, and call for the sack by and by - he gave it to my wife, and as he passed me he said, "The goose is in that;" there was one in it, which did not appear to have been killed above ten or twelve minutes - the head was nearly severed from the body; I put it into thesack again - I afterwards delivered the same geese to the officer.

Cross-examined. Q. Had the sack been out of your sight? A. It had not been out of my premises; he was not in the habit of selling geese; I meant by the cross, that he had come by it in a dishonest manner; I said I would have nothing to do with it, but he brought it.

SARAH PAYNE
. This is the head and wing of the goose.

COURT. Q. Had you fed and observed your geese? A. Yes; I had had them about three months - I can say, from my observation of it, this was one of mine; Southmimms is about fourteen miles from town, and Mr. Bull's is about three miles from me.

GUILTY . Aged 60. -
Confined Six Months .
OLD COURT. WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 11.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

499.
JAMES LITTLEBOY
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
John Dignall
, on the 14th of December , putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 purse, value 2d.; 8 shillings, 4 sixpences, and 3d., his property .
The prosecutor's name being Duiegnan, the prisoner was ACQUITTED .
Before Mr. Recorder.

500.
JOHN RICHARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of November , 12 silver spoons, value 3l.; 3 pairs of window-curtains, value 3l.; 12 brass books, value 5s., and 20 yards of braiding, value 5s., the goods of
Charles Wardsworth
, in his dwelling-house .
MR. BARRY conducted the prosecution.

JAMES AYLETT
. I am a gentleman's servant. In October and November I was in the service of Mr. Wardsworth; I had only been in his service a few days - I was at his dwelling-house, No. 3, Clifford-street, Bond-street
; I recollect the curtains in the front dining-room - they were red silk: they had been put up before I came into his service, which was five days or a week before this matter happened; I saw some books and rings - there was some braiding round the curtains, and there was a dozen silver spoons: I saw them about a quarter of an hour before this happened - they laid on a sideboard by the side of the fire-place. On the 18th of November I heard a knock at the door; I had been in the dining-room about a quarter of an hour before them, locked the door, and put the key under the mat, close by the door - it was then I saw the silver spoons; a woman, who was housekeeper, was in the house with me; on hearing the knock I opened the door, and saw the prisoner and Willis, who rushed in as soon as I opened it - Willis said, "I want to see Mr. Wardsworth;" I said he was not at home - before that he turned the handle of the parlour door, which was locked, and then ran up to the drawing-room; I followed him - he looked over the rooms, to satisfy himself that Mr. Wardsworth was not there - he looked over different rooms; he was up stairs four or five minutes; I then followed him down stairs, and saw the dining-room door open; Willis could not have opened it, because he was with me - nobody could have opened it but the prisoner - I found the prisoner in the dining-room alone, taking down the curtains; I asked what he wanted - he said, "My name is
John Richards
- these are mine;" Pattempted to lock him into the room - he took down a wire blind, opened the window, and was going to give them to a person who was waiting in the street; I have not seen that person since -I did not lock the door, and he gave them out to the person at the front door - they were all taken away; the spoons were also gone - I am sure the spoons were in the room ten minutes or a quarter of an hour before; Willis said to the prisoner, "What, have you taken them? mind, I have no hand in this."

Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. You had no previous acquaintance with the prosecutor? A. I had known him some little time before - I knew him when he was in the Marshalsea twelve months ago; I was not a creditor of his - I do not know the amount of the debt he was confined for - Clifford-street is a fashionable street; it is at the corner of Burlington-street; I was not acting as footman; I said I was his servant - I was out of livery; I was there about a week.

Q. You are not a broker who takes possession for other people? A. I have been in possession once for the prosecutor; I have been in a house with a bill of sale - I was in this house afterwards with a bill of sale, in possession for a person named Cooper; I went into possession on the evening of the 18th - the deed was executed that day.

Q. Then you having been servant to the prosecutor five days, on the fifth day take a bill of sale from Cooper to take your master's goods? A. I took a bill of sale - I was merely attending for Mr. Wardsworth while he got a little money advanced on the goods; I then became servant to Mr. Cooper - he is a wharfinger, and lives at Pickle Herring-wharf; I believe he has the bill of sale - the goods were all taken away; not under the bill of sale about a dozen men came in one day, and held me down while they took the goods away - I have been a brewer, and have very likely said that I was a broken down brewer; I was put in possession of the bill of sale about five or six o'clock, the same night the curtains were taken away, which was between eleven and twelve o'clock; my master had come home about five; I was put in possession - I had seen Cooper that day; I have seen him and my master visit, perhaps five or six times, about a year and a half ago - I do not know where the woman remained while I and Willis went up stairs; I believe Willis is a bailiff, and had come to arrest my master - the prisoner had been to the house the day before I believe; the goods were taken in open day.

Q. Now, be cautious, did you not say you were waiting in the house, and would not say you was in possession till more goods came in? A. No; nor that I would remain in the house as the prosecutor's servant, and not take possession till more goods came in, for it was not worth while - nor to that effect; I did not say I was waiting to take possession when more goods came in, nor any thing to that effect.

Q. When you went up stairs with the bailiff, was not the maid servant in the hall? A. No, I believe not - she is not here; I do not know where she is - I know I left her down stairs; there was no other servant in the house; I do not know Mr. Wilkinson, a pianoforte-maker - I recollect a person taking a pianoforte away; that might be a fortnight ago - no complaint was made against him, to my knowledge: the spoons which were taken were tea-spoons - I do not know where they were bought; I never heard master say he had a large quantity of plate coming home, with a crest on it; these had no crest - they were nearly new - I did not know Mr. Richards, the linen-draper; the bailiff did not say he had come to arrest master - he said he had a writ against him; the prisoner said he was Mr. Richards, and took away the curtains - I never went to Mr. Richards to claim the property back, nor did Mr. Wardsworth, to my knowledge.

Q. The spoons were never claimed by any body, only the curtains - then the spoons, at all events, must have been stolen? A. Certainly; I went before the Magistrate after I had a true bill found against him.
COURT. Q. A true bill could not be found till the Grand Jury sat - did you complain to any Magistrate? A. Not to my knowledge.

MR. ALLEY. The Sessions, if I remember, were on the 4th or 5th of December, at Clerknewell? A. It was at Westminster - my first appearance as an accuser was before the Grand Jury; I dare say that was about a fortnight after the goods were taken - I believe the prisoner was taken up the first day of the last Session; the prosecutor went to Mr. Clark's office, got a certificate of the indictment, and then went to the Magistrate - they took him that evening on the certificate, in Mr. Richard's shop.

Q. Did you take him before a Magistrate? A. No, he was taken to the Police-station, and then discharged; he was taken before Mr. Minshull about a fortnight or three weeks before Christmas - my master did not attend then to make a charge against him; I went there - I got there about half-past twelve o'clock; he was then liberated on bail - I went to inquire, and found him liberated; I did not go before the Magistrate.

Q. Now, look at this gentleman, (Mr. Harmer) - on your oath, do you mean to say you went at twelve or half-past twelve o'clock, and the prisoner was discharged? A. Half-past twelve o'clock; I went to inquire of Mr. Burchall - I went into the clerk's office, and inquired there.

Q. Do not you know that Mr. Minshull, hearing the story from Mr. Richard's employer, took his own recognizance to appear? A. I do not know, nor do I know that he has surrendered voluntarily, nor that he has never been in Newgate - I believe it.
COURT. Q. Did you see him as he walked here today? A. No.

MR. ALLEY. Q. Do not you know this trial stood over from morning to morning here for the prisoner to surrender? A. I have heard it; I do not know it - I was here yesterday, but I do not know that he was not tried because he was not in custody; I have not seen him waiting about to surrender - master has not told me that he had not surrendered; I have not received any notice of his intention to surrender, neither last Session nor this - I do not know that he has been on bail ever since; I was told he was on bail.

Q. During the five days you were there, a great many people came after your master? A. Yes, several people who came after bills for goods sold; very little came into the house while I was there - there were a few things, such as eatables and beer; no furniture, nor any thing of that kind.
Q. Am I to understand you to swear that no person came to take away different articles? A. After that they did.
Q. Alleging that they had been swindled out of them? A. Yes.
MR. BARRY. Q. An indictment was found against the prisoner? A. Yes; he was afterwards apprehended on a warrant, a fortnight or three weeks before Christmas.

COURT. Q. Did you know where he lived? A. Yes, because we had apprehended him - I do not know why he was not taken before; I merely went to identify him - I did not make any deposition; I told Mr. Wardsworth what had happened.

CHARLES WARDSWORTH
. I am quite out of business; I have been in the Manchester trade. In October and November I occupied the house, No. 3, Clifford-street, Bond-street; I had some dealings with
John Richards
and Co. of Oxford-street, and purchased the goods named in this bill,(looking at it); I bought some crimson silk curtains - I believe I had six brass hooks of Mr. Richards; the bill amounts to 31l. 19s. 10d. - I had known Mr. Richards about twenty-eight years; he said nothing about the mode of payment - I called on him before I ordered them: he had a very large stock of goods, and was very desirous of selling me goods to furnish my house; he proposed to me to purchase not only these, but other goods - I received the goods named in the invoice, part on the 19th of October, and part on the 28th; I had some servants to make the silk up into window-curtains - part of them were put up in Clifford-street; I used about three dozen hooks - I believe about two dozen were taken away with the curtains - I had purchased part of the braiding of Mr. Richards; that was part of the braiding included in the bill - I also used on the curtains other braiding, and hooks, besides those supplied by him; I was in the house on the morning of the 18th of November, and left between nine and ten o'clock, leaving Aylett behind - I had a woman in the house; I breakfasted in the parlour - the curtains were all up then, and there were a dozen silver spoons, which I intended to take away with me, had I not been obliged to go out on important business, and I left them on a small sideboard; I returned about five o'clock - the curtains and spoons were gone; I was informed a person, describing himself as Richards, had been there - I spoke to my solicitor, and the Sessions were just on; I immediately went to find the bill, the Session being two or three days after; it was the Westminster Sessions - I had a good deal to attend to of importance: I know I went the first day of Westminster Sessions, and found the bill.

Q. What did you do on finding the bill? A. I went to the Clerk of the Peace, in Carlisle-street, Soho, and I was to wait - I was referred to the Old Bailey; I applied here on the first day of the Session - Mr. Clark or his servant told me I must wait till the first day of the Session; I could not have a warrant till then, because the Jury must sit; I obtained the certificate, and got a Police-serjeant and his man that very evening, and took the party to identify him - I took him to the station-house in Marylebone-lane; there he was known to the party, and they discharged him - I was recommended to go to Scotland-yard against the Police; Iwent to Bow-street three or four weeks afterwards, and obtained a warrant, which was executed - I did not attend at Bow-street when he was taken on the warrant, because I did not know of it - I have not got any of my property back.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you sure you should know the property again if you saw it? A. I do not know that I should - I did not put the stitching in it; I did not make them - I was in business last at Manchester at Waterloo-place, Southwark, No. 2; I was in business there from the time of the panic till about two years ago - I was there from 1824 to 1828; I do not recollect what month in 1828 - I had a docket struck against me there, which I superseded; I left Waterloo-place about two days before Christmas - I have done a little commission business since that, in buying and selling malt; I was a spirit-merchant at Manchester - I have not dealt with many persons in the malt line in London.

Q. Were you in any line? A. I have got so many things in Chancery, I have done no business except buying a trifling article or two - I have done nothing but the malt commission business since I came to London.

Q. Where did you live first when you came to London? A. I stopped sometime at a public-house at Islington - I lived there three or four months; it is at the corner of Sun-street, about half a dozen doors from Finsbury-square - I got out of the coach at Islington, and stopped at the Green Man, opposite the Angel, about four days, and then came to lodge at this house; I do not recollect the sign - it is the corner of Sun-street and Crown-street; one end runs to Bishopsgate-street - I do not recollect the landlord's name: I paid him a week in advance for the lodging - I took no receipt, I had witnesses enough - I then took the remaining part of a lease from a person named Benjamin, in Union-court; I believe it was No. 13 - I was there about six months; it was No. 13 or 14, I do not know which - Mr. Stirtevant, the Common Councilman, was my landlord - I went from there to Stingo-lane, No. 8, and have lived there from that time to this, pretty well occasionally.

Q. The inquiry is not where your family lived, but where you yourself lived? A. All my family lived in Union-court; I lived in Stingo-lane two or three months - my family did not live there; I staid in Stingo-lane two or three months.

Q. Where did you go to from Stingo-lane? A. I lived at Sydney-terrace, Sydney-square, No. 2; my family lived there at the same time - I went from there to No. 10, Sutton-street, close by; I stopped there six months - I stopped three months myself, and left my family there; I think I was in Sydney-terrace near six months - I was arrested in Sutton-street, and went to the Marshalsea; I was arrested for three or four sums on some bills - I do not know the amount together; they swore to sums and upwards - I defended the actions myself; I have had a verdict for the third - and the fourth I compromised, to prevent any difficulties.

Q. After defending three actions, what was the sum you remained in prison for? A. Why, near 30l. - I remained there a few weeks for that sum; when one person arrested me, and went to trial - then they lodged a detainer; I was there about a month - I am married: I took two ladies to Mr. Richards - I was there four times, and think I took two; I am not quite positive: I did not take my wife there- it was after I got out of the Marshalsea; I did not tell Mr. Richards I had been in the Marshalsea - what occasion was there for that? he knew me when I had 1000l. in my pocket, and he had not 1s. - I did not promise to pay him ready money for the goods; I bought the spoons in question from Thomas Wilkinson, Piccadilly - here is the bill and receipt: they amount to 4l. 6s.; they were paid for before they were stolen - I never had an office in Somerset-house; I did not represent to Mr. Richards that I had an office in Somerset-house, nor a place, nor any employment there, nothing of the kind; I never said so to the prisoner, or to any body.

Q. Did you not say to him, when he came with 7l. worth of goods, which is the last portion, that you could not pay him till you got your money, but you would pay him when the quarter was up? A. No, nothing of the kind - if any body has said so, it is pure invention; these were the only spoons I had in the house, and the only ones I had bought - my wife was down at my brother's, in Hertfordshire, at the time; I have four children - two were in Clifford-street; one is concerned in a steam-packet, the other was now and then at Clifford-street - sometimes he was at Margate; I had looked at some other spoons, but not ordered them in, nor had I ordered any plate.

Q. There was a bill of sale at the time Richards took your things - you were removing from Clifford-street? A. No, I was not, but I was pressed very much by Mr. Bailey, and had immediately to raise about 700l., and I had seventeen workmen there - I ordered some plate afterwards from Mr. Hamlet: whether he was to supply me depended on the price - I had looked at a considerable quantity of second-hand plate.

Q. Did you bespeak any plate of any body else - I am not talking of looking at it? A. I think I did, of Mr. Thomas, in Bond-street; I bespoke none of any other, to my knowledge, except to Mr. Wilkinson - I believe I ordered no more; I might go into a shop, but I believe not- I am sure I did not bespeak any other plate.
Q. Did you apply for any - did you try to get any from any body else? A. No, I did not - I swear that; I do not know Mr. Oswald.

Q. In Great Russell-street - now, I tell you he is in Court? A. Oh, I will tell you; I went to look at a tea-pot there, because I did expect a sum of money - I told him to put my initials on it, but I should not take it till I got the money, and begged him to take care of it till I did - I wanted nothing but the tea-pot, and did not want to get that, for I left word I should not have it; it was taken to my house to be seen, certainly - I believe I told Mr. Oswald I wished my wife to see it; she was not living in the house then, but she would be in town in a day or two; I did not tell him I wanted a large service of plate - I said if he had got any thing cheap, I should want some - I was furnishing a house, and laid out a great deal of money; I cannot say how many persons I bought goods of on credit - I will tell you why I could not pay my way; my landlord was ill, and kept me three months without a lease, that kept me out of about 300l., which I expected, and I expected to receive some money from Manchester - other tradesmen, whom I had bought goods of, took them out of my house; no one took them by force, to my knowledge.

Q. That you will swear? A. Yes; Mr. Bailey and Mr. Wilkinson did not indict either of them for robbery- Mr. Wilkinson never applied at all, to my knowledge, for payment for his pianoforte; he, Mr. Bailey, and all came together - there were twelve or fourteen of them and their men, but I was not there; I did not take any steps - Mr. Bailey sent in a bill for 400l.; the painoforte was about 70l. I sent to Mr. Bailey, about three weeks before, that I should give him the security of a gentleman in the Lord Chamberlain's-office - I owed Mr. Plasket, the wine-merchant, 30l., Mr. Goodey, a tailor, 16l., but he owes me a little, I had some child's clothes from Mr. Lock, another tailor; I owe Mr. Whiteley, an ironmonger of Holborn, 7l.; I offered Mr. Bailey security; I told him if he was not satisfied with a gentleman he was acquainted with not to serve me, not to send any thing, and when he sent me about 20l. worth I said, "Go to the Lord Chamberlain's-office, and ask your friend again;" then he sent them - I do not know whether he took the goods away; they are not in the house now -
James Rivett
is the person in the Chamberlain's-office; he holds a berth there now: he gives his name on the card, and I believe he is there to-day; I do not know that he became security - I owe Mr. Foster, a linen-draper of Oxford-street, 8l. or 9l., and Mr. Blaket, of Regent-street, 8l. or 9l., Mr. Mortlock, a chinaman, of Regent-street, 40l. - I believe Mr. Williams, a silk-mercer, claims 4l.; I was to pay 160 guineas a year rent for the house in Clifford-street, besides taxes; I was to do all the repairs before I had the lease.

Q. Tell me the name of the attorney you went to after Mr. Richards robbed you? A. I mentioned it to Mr. Reynolds, of Clement-street, Kingsland-road, and to his clerk: I never saw Richard Miller, who is now a Policeman, letter C. No. 50 - I came out of the Marshalsea more than twelve months ago; I do not remember after that being in a public-house in Fleet-lane with
Richard Miller
and some women - I might be in Fleet lane; I remember a man, named Biggers, in Fleet-lane; I do not know a woman named Cann - I have heard of a woman named Jenkins; I was many times in Fleet-lane, next door to Biggers', at a public-house.

Q. Were you drinking in company with two women and a man there, Mrs. Jenkins being one of them? A. Very likely - I am sure I was; I have no doubt but I told a man there that I had been just discharged from the Marshalsea.

Q. The man I allude to is Richard Miller - did you ever tell him you were acting with others in getting goods and selling them? A. Never - that I am sure of; (looking at Miller) I do not recollect him - I never recollect seeing him; I might be drinking with him at a public-house in Fleet-lane - I was not a gentleman then.

Q. On your solemn oath, did you never tell a man that you were employed acting with others in getting goods and selling them, and did you not propose to Miller to join you? A.
